description: From international scientific vocabulary, from German Dysarthrie, from New Latin, using the combining forms dys- +‎ arthr- +‎ -ia.

entries.meaning: (neurology, neuropsychology) Difficulty in articulating words due to a disturbance in the form or function of the structures that modulate voice into speech; one of the first indicative symptoms of myasthenia gravis, brought about by an autoimmune response to acetylcholine receptors.
